title: CycloneDX Transparency Expression Language
$comment: OWASP CycloneDX is an Ecma International standard (ECMA-424) developed in collaboration between the OWASP Foundation and Ecma Technical Committee 54 (TC54). The standard is published under a royalty-free patent policy. This JSON schema is the reference implementation and is licensed under the Apache License 2.0.

specFormat.title: Specification Format
specFormat.description: Specifies the format. This value must be "CycloneDX".

specVersion.title: Specification Version
specVersion.description: The version of the CycloneDX specification the BOM conforms to.

serialNumber.title: BOM Serial Number
serialNumber.description: Every BOM generated SHOULD have a unique serial number, even if the contents of the BOM have not changed over time. If specified, the serial number must conform to [RFC 4122](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc4122.html). Use of serial numbers is recommended.

version.title: BOM Version
version.description: Whenever an existing BOM is modified, either manually or through automated processes, the version of the BOM SHOULD be incremented by 1. When a system is presented with multiple BOMs with identical serial numbers, the system SHOULD use the most recent version of the BOM. The default version is '1'.

components.description: A collection of components. When a metadata component is present, this array represents the inventory of components associated with that subject, forming a bill of materials. When the metadata component is omitted, the array provides component data for interchange purposes without establishing a compositional relationship.

modelCard.title: Model Card
modelCard.description: A model card describes the intended uses of a machine learning model and potential limitations, including biases and ethical considerations. Model cards typically contain the training parameters, which datasets were used to train the model, performance metrics, and other relevant data useful for ML transparency. This object SHOULD be specified for any component of type `machine-learning-model` and must not be specified for other component types.

bom-ref.title: BOM Reference
bom-ref.description:
An identifier which can be used to reference the model card elsewhere in the BOM. Every `bom-ref` must be unique within the BOM.
Value SHOULD not start with the BOM-Link intro 'urn:cdx:' to avoid conflicts with BOM-Links.

modelParameters.title: Model Parameters
modelParameters.description: Hyper-parameters for construction of the model.

approach.title: Approach
approach.description: The overall approach to learning used by the model for problem solving.

type.title: Learning Type
type.description: Learning types describing the learning problem or hybrid learning problem.

meta:enum.supervised: Supervised machine learning involves training an algorithm on labeled data to predict or classify new data based on the patterns learned from the labeled examples.
meta:enum.unsupervised: Unsupervised machine learning involves training algorithms on unlabeled data to discover patterns, structures, or relationships without explicit guidance, allowing the model to identify inherent structures or clusters within the data.
meta:enum.reinforcement-learning: Reinforcement learning is a type of machine learning where an agent learns to make decisions by interacting with an environment to maximize cumulative rewards, through trial and error.
meta:enum.semi-supervised: Semi-supervised machine learning utilizes a combination of labeled and unlabeled data during training to improve model performance, leveraging the benefits of both supervised and unsupervised learning techniques.
meta:enum.self-supervised: Self-supervised machine learning involves training models to predict parts of the input data from other parts of the same data, without requiring external labels, enabling learning from large amounts of unlabeled data.

task.title: Task
task.description: Directly influences the input and/or output. Examples include classification, regression, clustering, etc.

architectureFamily.title: Architecture Family
architectureFamily.description: The model architecture family such as transformer network, convolutional neural network, residual neural network, LSTM neural network, etc.

modelArchitecture.title: Model Architecture
modelArchitecture.description: The specific architecture of the model such as GPT-1, ResNet-50, YOLOv3, etc.

datasets.title: Datasets
datasets.description: The datasets used to train and evaluate the model.

ref.title: Reference
ref.description: References a data component by the components bom-ref attribute

inputs.title: Inputs
inputs.description: The input format(s) of the model

outputs.title: Outputs
outputs.description: The output format(s) from the model

quantitativeAnalysis.title: Quantitative Analysis
quantitativeAnalysis.description: A quantitative analysis of the model

performanceMetrics.title: Performance Metrics
performanceMetrics.description: The model performance metrics being reported. Examples may include accuracy, F1 score, precision, top-3 error rates, MSC, etc.

considerations.title: Considerations
considerations.description: What considerations should be taken into account regarding the model's construction, training, and application?

users.title: Users
users.description: Who are the intended users of the model?

useCases.title: Use Cases
useCases.description: What are the intended use cases of the model?

technicalLimitations.title: Technical Limitations
technicalLimitations.description: What are the known technical limitations of the model? E.g. What kind(s) of data should the model be expected not to perform well on? What are the factors that might degrade model performance?

performanceTradeoffs.title: Performance Tradeoffs
performanceTradeoffs.description: What are the known tradeoffs in accuracy/performance of the model?

ethicalConsiderations.title: Ethical Considerations
ethicalConsiderations.description: What are the ethical risks involved in the application of this model?

environmentalConsiderations.title: Environmental Considerations
environmentalConsiderations.description: What are the various environmental impacts the corresponding machine learning model has exhibited across its lifecycle?

fairnessAssessments.title: Fairness Assessments
fairnessAssessments.description: How does the model affect groups at risk of being systematically disadvantaged? What are the harms and benefits to the various affected groups?

format.title: Input/Output Format
format.description: The data format for input/output to the model.

energyConsumptions.title: Energy Consumptions
energyConsumptions.description: Describes energy consumption information incurred for one or more component lifecycle activities.

properties.title: Properties
properties.description: Provides the ability to document properties in a name-value store. This provides flexibility to include data not officially supported in the standard without having to use additional namespaces or create extensions. Unlike key-value stores, properties support duplicate names, each potentially having different values. Property names of interest to the general public are encouraged to be registered in the [CycloneDX Property Taxonomy](https://github.com/CycloneDX/cyclonedx-property-taxonomy). Formal registration is optional.

energyConsumption.title: Energy consumption
energyConsumption.description: Describes energy consumption information incurred for the specified lifecycle activity.

activity.title: Activity
activity.description: The type of activity that is part of a machine learning model development or operational lifecycle.

meta:enum.design: A model design including problem framing, goal definition and algorithm selection.
meta:enum.data-collection: Model data acquisition including search, selection and transfer.
meta:enum.data-preparation: Model data preparation including data cleaning, labeling and conversion.
meta:enum.training: Model building, training and generalized tuning.
meta:enum.fine-tuning: Refining a trained model to produce desired outputs for a given problem space.
meta:enum.validation: Model validation including model output evaluation and testing.
meta:enum.deployment: Explicit model deployment to a target hosting infrastructure.
meta:enum.inference: Generating an output response from a hosted model from a set of inputs.
meta:enum.other: A lifecycle activity type whose description does not match currently defined values.

energyProviders.title: Energy Providers
energyProviders.description: The provider(s) of the energy consumed by the associated model development lifecycle activity.

activityEnergyCost.title: Activity Energy Cost
activityEnergyCost.description: The total energy cost associated with the model lifecycle activity.

co2CostEquivalent.title: CO2 Equivalent Cost
co2CostEquivalent.description: The CO2 cost (debit) equivalent to the total energy cost.

co2CostOffset.title: CO2 Cost Offset
co2CostOffset.description: The CO2 offset (credit) for the CO2 equivalent cost.

properties.title: Properties
properties.description: Provides the ability to document properties in a name-value store. This provides flexibility to include data not officially supported in the standard without having to use additional namespaces or create extensions. Unlike key-value stores, properties support duplicate names, each potentially having different values. Property names of interest to the general public are encouraged to be registered in the [CycloneDX Property Taxonomy](https://github.com/CycloneDX/cyclonedx-property-taxonomy). Formal registration is optional.

meta:enum.kWh: Kilowatt-hour (kWh) is the energy delivered by one kilowatt (kW) of power for one hour (h).

energyProvider.title: Energy Provider
energyProvider.description: Describes the physical provider of energy used for model development or operations.

bom-ref.title: BOM Reference
bom-ref.description:
An identifier which can be used to reference the energy provider elsewhere in the BOM. Every `bom-ref` must be unique within the BOM.
Value SHOULD not start with the BOM-Link intro 'urn:cdx:' to avoid conflicts with BOM-Links.

description.title: Description
description.description: A description of the energy provider.

meta:enum.coal: Energy produced by types of coal.
meta:enum.oil: Petroleum products (primarily crude oil and its derivative fuel oils).
meta:enum.natural-gas: Hydrocarbon gas liquids (HGL) that occur as gases at atmospheric pressure and as liquids under higher pressures including Natural gas (C5H12 and heavier), Ethane (C2H6), Propane (C3H8), etc.
meta:enum.nuclear: Energy produced from the cores of atoms (i.e., through nuclear fission or fusion).
meta:enum.solar: Energy produced from the sun (i.e., solar radiation).
meta:enum.geothermal: Energy produced from heat within the earth.
meta:enum.biofuel: Liquid fuels produced from biomass feedstocks (i.e., organic materials such as plants or animals).
meta:enum.other: An energy source that is not listed.

energySource.title: Energy Source
energySource.description: The energy source for the energy provider.

energyProvided.title: Energy Provided
energyProvided.description: The energy provided by the energy source for an associated activity.

externalReferences.title: External References
externalReferences.description: External references provide a way to document systems, sites, and information that may be relevant but are not included with the BOM. They may also establish specific relationships within or external to the BOM.

graphicsCollection.title: Graphics Collection
graphicsCollection.description: A collection of graphics that represent various measurements.

description.title: Description
description.description: A description of this collection of graphics.

image.title: Graphic Image
image.description: The graphic (vector or raster). Base64 encoding must be specified for binary images.

type.title: Type
type.description: The type of performance metric.

value.title: Value
value.description: The value of the performance metric.

slice.title: Slice
slice.description: The name of the slice this metric was computed on. By default, assume this metric is not sliced.

confidenceInterval.title: Confidence Interval
confidenceInterval.description: The confidence interval of the metric.

lowerBound.title: Lower Bound
lowerBound.description: The lower bound of the confidence interval.

upperBound.title: Upper Bound
upperBound.description: The upper bound of the confidence interval.

mitigationStrategy.title: Mitigation Strategy
mitigationStrategy.description: Strategy used to address this risk.

fairnessAssessment.title: Fairness Assessment
fairnessAssessment.description: Information about the benefits and harms of the model to an identified at risk group.

groupAtRisk.title: Group at Risk
groupAtRisk.description: The groups or individuals at risk of being systematically disadvantaged by the model.

benefits.title: Benefits
benefits.description: Expected benefits to the identified groups.

harms.title: Harms
harms.description: Expected harms to the identified groups.

mitigationStrategy.title: Mitigation Strategy
mitigationStrategy.description: With respect to the benefits and harms outlined, please describe any mitigation strategy implemented.

annotations.title: Annotations
annotations.description: Comments made by people, organizations, or tools about any object with a bom-ref, such as components, services, vulnerabilities, or the BOM itself. Unlike inventory information, annotations may contain opinions or commentary from various stakeholders. Annotations may be inline (with inventory) or externalized via BOM-Link and may optionally be signed.

annotation.title: Annotations
annotation.description: A comment, note, explanation, or similar textual content which provides additional context to the object(s) being annotated.

bom-ref.title: BOM Reference
bom-ref.description:
An identifier which can be used to reference the annotation elsewhere in the BOM. Every `bom-ref` must be unique within the BOM.
Value SHOULD not start with the BOM-Link intro 'urn:cdx:' to avoid conflicts with BOM-Links.

subjects.title: Subjects
subjects.description: The object in the BOM identified by its bom-ref. This is often a component or service, but may be any object type supporting bom-refs.

annotator.title: Annotator
annotator.description: The organization, person, component, or service which created the textual content of the annotation.

organization.description: The organization that created the annotation

individual.description: The person that created the annotation

component.description: The tool or component that created the annotation

service.description: The service that created the annotation

timestamp.title: Timestamp
timestamp.description: The date and time (timestamp) when the annotation was created.

text.title: Text
text.description: The textual content of the annotation.

trigger.title: Trigger
trigger.description: The condition or event that initiates a behavior.

meta:enum.startup: Triggered during system or component initialisation.
meta:enum.shutdown: Triggered during system or component termination.
meta:enum.scheduled: Triggered at predetermined times or intervals.
meta:enum.event-driven: Triggered in response to a specific event.
meta:enum.signal: Triggered by a system or inter-process signal.
meta:enum.condition-based: Triggered when specific conditions are met.
meta:enum.unknown: The trigger mechanism is not known.

ordering.title: Ordering
ordering.description: Execution semantics for steps within a flow.

meta:enum.sequential: Steps execute in ordinal order. Each completes before the next begins.
meta:enum.unordered: All steps execute, but order is not guaranteed.
meta:enum.conditional: Step execution is determined by runtime conditions.

acknowledgment.title: Acknowledgment
acknowledgment.description: Indicates how the behavior or flow was identified. Multiple values indicate the behavior was both declared and observed.

meta:enum.declared: The behavior was explicitly declared, designed, or expected. Typically used for threat modelling, security requirements, and architectural documentation.
meta:enum.observed: The behavior was observed, detected, or measured during analysis or runtime. Typically used for anomaly detection, incident response, and behavioural analysis.

behaviors.title: Behaviors
behaviors.description: Behaviors performed by objects within the BOM.

flows.title: Flows
flows.description: Behavior flows that organise behaviors into operational patterns.

behaviorInstance.title: Behavior Instance
behaviorInstance.description: A behavior performed by one or more objects within the BOM.

actors.title: Actors
actors.description: References to objects that perform this behavior.

targets.title: Targets
targets.description: References to objects affected by this behavior.

behaviorFlow.title: Behavior Flow
behaviorFlow.description: An organised collection of behaviors forming a coherent process.

steps.title: Steps
steps.description: The steps that comprise this flow.

flowStep.title: Flow Step
flowStep.description: A single step within a behavior flow.

ordinal.title: Ordinal
ordinal.description: Position within the flow. Required when ordering is 'sequential' or omitted.

behavior.title: Behavior
behavior.description: The behavior performed in this step. Mutually exclusive with 'ref' and 'flow'.

ref.title: Behavior Reference
ref.description: Reference to a behavior instance. Mutually exclusive with 'behavior' and 'flow'.

flow.title: Flow Reference
flow.description: Reference to a nested flow. Mutually exclusive with 'behavior' and 'ref'.

actors.title: Actors
actors.description: References to objects that perform this step.

targets.title: Targets
targets.description: References to objects affected by this step.

behavior.title: Behavior
behavior.description: Specifies an action performed by an entity that may have security, privacy, safety, or operational implications. Values may represent a domain, a category within a domain, or a specific behavior within a category.

meta:enum.ai: Behaviours relating to artificial intelligence and machine learning operations.
meta:enum.ai:agent: Behaviours that enable autonomous agents to plan and execute tasks.
meta:enum.ai:agent:actsOnBehalfOfUser: The entity performs actions within a delegated user context.
meta:enum.ai:agent:delegatesTask: The entity assigns work to another agent.
meta:enum.ai:agent:plansAction: The entity determines steps to achieve goal.
meta:enum.ai:agent:receivesHumanDelegation: The entity accepts authority delegated by a human user.
meta:enum.ai:agent:reportsDelegatedAction: The entity notifies the delegating user of actions taken.
meta:enum.ai:agent:requestsUserApproval: The entity seeks explicit user authorisation before acting.
meta:enum.ai:agent:revisesPlan: The entity modifies approach based on results.
meta:enum.ai:explainability: Behaviours that provide interpretable explanations for model decisions.
meta:enum.ai:explainability:documentsModel: The entity records model design and behaviour.
meta:enum.ai:explainability:tracesPrediction: The entity records basis for output.
meta:enum.ai:explainability:visualizesModel: The entity renders model behaviour graphically.
meta:enum.ai:fairness: Behaviours that detect and mitigate bias in machine learning models.
meta:enum.ai:fairness:auditsModelFairness: The entity evaluates model for bias.
meta:enum.ai:fairness:detectsBias: The entity identifies unfair model behaviour.
meta:enum.ai:generative: Behaviours that produce content using generative models.
meta:enum.ai:generative:mitigatesHallucination: The entity reduces false content generation.
meta:enum.ai:inference: Behaviours that generate predictions using trained models.
meta:enum.ai:inference:batchesInference: The entity processes multiple inputs together.
meta:enum.ai:inference:cachesPrediction: The entity stores prediction for reuse.
meta:enum.ai:inference:ensemblesModels: The entity combines multiple model outputs.
meta:enum.ai:inference:infersInRealTime: The entity generates prediction with low latency.
meta:enum.ai:inference:ranksResults: The entity orders predictions by relevance.
meta:enum.ai:inference:scoresConfidence: The entity assigns certainty to prediction.
meta:enum.ai:management: Behaviours that deploy and manage machine learning models throughout their lifecycle.
meta:enum.ai:management:comparesModels: The entity evaluates relative model performance.
meta:enum.ai:management:deploysModel: The entity places model into service.
meta:enum.ai:management:loadsModel: The entity retrieves model for use.
meta:enum.ai:management:retiresModel: The entity removes model from service.
meta:enum.ai:management:rollsBackModel: The entity reverts to previous version.
meta:enum.ai:management:unloadsModel: The entity removes model from memory.
meta:enum.ai:quality: Behaviours that monitor and maintain model and data quality.
meta:enum.ai:quality:detectsConceptDrift: The entity identifies input-output relationship change.
meta:enum.ai:quality:detectsDataDrift: The entity identifies input distribution change.
meta:enum.ai:quality:engineersFeatures: The entity transforms raw data for model.
meta:enum.ai:quality:selectsFeatures: The entity chooses relevant input features.
meta:enum.ai:quality:validatesInputData: The entity checks inference input quality.
meta:enum.ai:robustness: Behaviours that defend against adversarial attacks and handle uncertain inputs.
meta:enum.ai:robustness:detectsAdversarialInput: The entity identifies crafted malicious input.

meta:enum.ai:training:preprocessesTrainingData: The entity prepares data for training.
meta:enum.ai:training:trainsFederatedly: The entity trains on distributed data.
meta:enum.ai:training:validatesModel: The entity evaluates model during training.
meta:enum.ai:training:validatesTrainingData: The entity checks training data quality.

meta:enum.application:codeExecution:interpretsCode: The entity executes code without compilation.

meta:enum.application:codeExecution:loadsCodeDynam: The entity loads executable code at runtime.

meta:enum.application:controlFlow:schedulesAsyncOp: The entity queues work for later execution.

meta:enum.application:observability:recordsMetric: The entity captures a quantitative measurement.
meta:enum.application:observability:tracesRequest: The entity tracks request across services.

meta:enum.application:requestHandling:routesReques: The entity directs request to appropriate handler.

meta:enum.application:responseGeneration:sendsHttp: The entity transmits an HTTP response.
meta:enum.application:responseGeneration:setsCooki: The entity creates or modifies a cookie.
meta:enum.application:responseGeneration:setsHeade: The entity adds HTTP header to response.

meta:enum.application:stateManagement:synchronizes: The entity maintains consistency across replicas.

meta:enum.data:encoding:encodesBaseSixtyFour: The entity converts data to Base64.
meta:enum.data:encoding:encodesUrl: The entity converts data for URL inclusion.
meta:enum.data:ingestion: Behaviours that acquire data from external sources.
meta:enum.data:ingestion:pollsSource: The entity periodically checks for new data.

meta:enum.data:ingestion:readsStream: The entity consumes data from a continuous source.
meta:enum.data:ingestion:receivesInput: The entity accepts data from an external source.
meta:enum.data:ingestion:receivesMessage: The entity accepts a message from a queue.
meta:enum.data:ingestion:receivesRequest: The entity accepts an incoming request.
meta:enum.data:ingestion:subscribesToFeed: The entity registers to receive updates.

meta:enum.data:output:producesOutput: The entity generates data for consumption.
meta:enum.data:output:publishesMessage: The entity sends a message to a queue.
meta:enum.data:output:rendersTemplate: The entity generates output from a template.

meta:enum.data:parsing:extractsFields: The entity isolates specific data elements.

meta:enum.data:query:queriesData: The entity retrieves data matching criteria.

meta:enum.data:transformation:enrichesData: The entity adds information from external sources.
meta:enum.data:transformation:joinsData: The entity combines data from multiple sources.
meta:enum.data:transformation:mapsData: The entity converts between data structures.
meta:enum.data:transformation:normalizesData: The entity converts to standard form.
meta:enum.data:transformation:transformsData: The entity converts data from one form to another.

^ext:[a-zA-Z0-9.-]+\\.[a-zA-Z]{2,}:.+$.description:
CycloneDX supports a structured and namespace-aware mechanism for extensibility through the use of extensible properties. This mechanism enables organizations, ecosystems, and tool vendors to safely introduce custom properties without conflicting with the core schema or other extensions.

Extensible properties are defined as a JSON object whose keys must conform to a strict pattern that resembles a reverse domain name structure, prefixed with ext:. This pattern provides a namespacing convention that aligns with well-established practices in other structured formats (e.g., XML namespaces).

Refer to [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OS-level_virtualization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OS-level_virtualization).
meta:enum.platform: A runtime environment that interprets or executes software. This may include runtimes such as those that execute bytecode, just-in-time compilers, interpreters, or low-code/no-code application platforms.
meta:enum.operating-system: A software operating system without regard to deployment model (i.e. installed on physical hardware, virtual machine, image, etc) Refer to [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operating_system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operating_system).
meta:enum.device: A hardware device such as a processor or chip-set. A hardware device containing firmware SHOULD include a component for the physical hardware itself and another component of type 'firmware' or 'operating-system' (whichever is relevant), describing information about the software running on the device. See also the list of [known device properties](https://github.com/CycloneDX/cyclonedx-property-taxonomy/blob/main/cdx/device.md).
meta:enum.device-driver: A special type of software that operates or controls a particular type of device. Refer to [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Device_driver](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Device_driver).
meta:enum.firmware: A special type of software that provides low-level control over a device's hardware. Refer to [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Firmware](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Firmware).
meta:enum.file: A computer file. Refer to [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_file](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_file) for information about files.
meta:enum.machine-learning-model: A model based on training data that can make predictions or decisions without being explicitly programmed to do so.
meta:enum.data: A collection of discrete values that convey information.
meta:enum.cryptographic-asset: A cryptographic asset including algorithms, protocols, certificates, keys, tokens, and secrets.

type.title: Component Type
type.description: Specifies the type of component. For software components, classify as application if no more specific appropriate classification is available or cannot be determined for the component.

mime-type.title: Mime-Type
mime-type.description: The mime-type of the component. When used on file components, the mime-type can provide additional context about the kind of file being represented, such as an image, font, or executable. Some library or framework components may also have an associated mime-type.

bom-ref.title: BOM Reference
bom-ref.description:
An identifier which can be used to reference the component elsewhere in the BOM. Every `bom-ref` must be unique within the BOM.
Value SHOULD not start with the BOM-Link intro 'urn:cdx:' to avoid conflicts with BOM-Links.

supplier.title: Component Supplier
supplier.description: The organization that supplied the component. The supplier may often be the manufacturer, but may also be a distributor or repackager.

manufacturer.title: Component Manufacturer
manufacturer.description:
The organization that created the component.
Manufacturer is common in components created through automated processes. Components created through manual means may have `@.authors` instead.

authors.title: Component Authors
authors.description:
The person(s) who created the component.
Authors are common in components created through manual processes. Components created through automated means may have `@.manufacturer` instead.

publisher.title: Component Publisher
publisher.description: The person(s) or organization(s) that published the component

group.title: Component Group
group.description: The grouping name or identifier. This will often be a shortened, single name of the company or project that produced the component, or the source package or domain name. Whitespace and special characters should be avoided. Examples include: apache, org.apache.commons, and apache.org.

name.title: Component Name
name.description: The name of the component. This will often be a shortened, single name of the component. Examples: commons-lang3 and jquery

version.title: Component Version
version.description:
The component version. The version should ideally comply with semantic versioning but is not enforced.
Must be used exclusively, either 'version' or 'versionRange', but not both.

versionRange.title: Component Version Range
versionRange.description:
For an external component, this specifies the accepted version range.
The value must adhere to the Package URL Version Range syntax (vers), as defined at <https://github.com/package-url/vers-spec
May only be used if `.isExternal` is set to `true`.
Must be used exclusively, either 'version' or 'versionRange', but not both.

isExternal.title: Component Is External
isExternal.description:
Determine whether this component is external.
An external component is one that is not part of an assembly, but is expected to be provided by the environment, regardless of the component's `.scope`. This setting can be useful for distinguishing which components are bundled with the product and which can be relied upon to be present in the deployment environment.
This may be set to `true` for runtime components only. For `$.metadata.component`, it must be set to `false`.

description.title: Component Description
description.description: Specifies a description for the component

meta:enum.required: The component is required for runtime
meta:enum.optional: The component is optional at runtime. Optional components are components that are not capable of being called due to them not being installed or otherwise accessible by any means. Components that are installed but due to configuration or other restrictions are prohibited from being called must be scoped as 'required'.
meta:enum.excluded: Components that are excluded provide the ability to document component usage for test and other non-runtime purposes. Excluded components are not reachable within a call graph at runtime.

scope.title: Component Scope
scope.description: Specifies the scope of the component. If scope is not specified, 'required' scope SHOULD be assumed by the consumer of the BOM.

cpe.title: Common Platform Enumeration (CPE)
cpe.description: Asserts the identity of the component using CPE. The CPE must conform to the CPE 2.2 or 2.3 specification. See [https://nvd.nist.gov/products/cpe](https://nvd.nist.gov/products/cpe). Refer to `@.evidence.identity` to optionally provide evidence that substantiates the assertion of the component's identity.

purl.title: Package URL (purl)
purl.description: Asserts the identity of the component using package-url (purl). The purl, if specified, must be valid and conform to the specification defined at: [https://github.com/package-url/purl-spec](https://github.com/package-url/purl-spec). Refer to `@.evidence.identity` to optionally provide evidence that substantiates the assertion of the component's identity.

omniborId.title: OmniBOR Artifact Identifier (gitoid)
omniborId.description: Asserts the identity of the component using the OmniBOR Artifact ID. The OmniBOR, if specified, must be valid and conform to the specification defined at: [https://www.iana.org/assignments/uri-schemes/prov/gitoid](https://www.iana.org/assignments/uri-schemes/prov/gitoid). Refer to `@.evidence.identity` to optionally provide evidence that substantiates the assertion of the component's identity.

swhid.title: Software Heritage Identifier
swhid.description: Asserts the identity of the component using the Software Heritage persistent identifier (SWHID). The SWHID, if specified, must be valid and conform to the specification defined at: [https://docs.softwareheritage.org/devel/swh-model/persistent-identifiers.html](https://docs.softwareheritage.org/devel/swh-model/persistent-identifiers.html). Refer to `@.evidence.identity` to optionally provide evidence that substantiates the assertion of the component's identity.

swid.title: SWID Tag
swid.description: Asserts the identity of the component using [ISO-IEC 19770-2 Software Identification (SWID) Tags](https://www.iso.org/standard/65666.html). Refer to `@.evidence.identity` to optionally provide evidence that substantiates the assertion of the component's identity.

pedigree.title: Component Pedigree
pedigree.description: Component pedigree is a way to document complex supply chain scenarios where components are created, distributed, modified, redistributed, combined with other components, etc. Pedigree supports viewing this complex chain from the beginning, the end, or anywhere in the middle. It also provides a way to document variants where the exact relation may not be known.

ancestors.title: Ancestors
ancestors.description: Describes zero or more components in which a component is derived from. This is commonly used to describe forks from existing projects where the forked version contains an ancestor node containing the original component it was forked from. For example, Component A is the original component. Component B is the component being used and documented in the BOM. However, Component B contains a pedigree node with a single ancestor documenting Component A - the original component from which Component B is derived from.

descendants.title: Descendants
descendants.description: Descendants are the exact opposite of ancestors. This provides a way to document all forks (and their forks) of an original or root component.

variants.title: Variants
variants.description: Variants describe relations where the relationship between the components is not known. For example, if Component A contains nearly identical code to Component B. They are both related, but it is unclear if one is derived from the other, or if they share a common ancestor.

commits.title: Commits
commits.description: A list of zero or more commits which provide a trail describing how the component deviates from an ancestor, descendant, or variant.

patches.title: Patches
patches.description: >A list of zero or more patches describing how the component deviates from an ancestor, descendant, or variant. Patches may be complementary to commits or may be used in place of commits.

notes.title: Notes
notes.description: Notes, observations, and other non-structured commentary describing the components pedigree.

components.title: Components
components.description: A list of software and hardware components included in the parent component. This is not a dependency tree. It provides a way to specify a hierarchical representation of component assemblies, similar to system → subsystem → parts assembly in physical supply chains.

evidence.title: Evidence
evidence.description: Provides the ability to document evidence collected through various forms of extraction or analysis.

data.title: Data
data.description: This object SHOULD be specified for any component of type `data` and must not be specified for other component types.

allOf.description: Requirement: ensure that `version` and `versionRange` are not present simultaneously.
Requirement: 'versionRange' must not be present when 'isExternal' is `false`.

version.description: A single disjunctive version identifier, for a component or service.

versionRange.description: A version range specified in Package-URL Version Range syntax (vers) which is defined at https://github.com/package-url/vers-spec

copyrightText.title: Component Copyright
copyrightText.description: A copyright notice informing users of the underlying claims to copyright ownership in a published work.

copyright.title: Copyright
copyright.description: Captures intellectual property assertions, providing evidence of possible ownership and legal protection.

copyrightObject.title: Copyright
copyrightObject.description: A copyright notice informing users of the underlying claims to copyright ownership in a published work.

text.title: Copyright Text
text.description: The textual content of the copyright.

swid.title: SWID Tag
swid.description: Specifies metadata and content for ISO-IEC 19770-2 Software Identification (SWID) Tags.

tagId.title: Tag ID
tagId.description: Maps to the tagId of a SoftwareIdentity.

name.title: Name
name.description: Maps to the name of a SoftwareIdentity.

version.title: Version
version.description: Maps to the version of a SoftwareIdentity.

tagVersion.title: Tag Version
tagVersion.description: Maps to the tagVersion of a SoftwareIdentity.

patch.title: Patch
patch.description: Maps to the patch of a SoftwareIdentity.

text.title: Attachment text
text.description: Specifies the metadata and content of the SWID tag.

url.title: URL
url.description: The URL to the SWID file.

componentEvidence.title: Evidence
componentEvidence.description: Provides the ability to document evidence collected through various forms of extraction or analysis.

identity.title: Identity Evidence
identity.description: Evidence that substantiates the identity of a component. The identity may be an object or an array of identity objects. Support for specifying identity as a single object was introduced in CycloneDX v1.5. Arrays were introduced in v1.6. It is recommended that all implementations use arrays, even if only one identity object is specified.

occurrences.title: Occurrences
occurrences.description: Evidence of individual instances of a component spread across multiple locations.

bom-ref.title: BOM Reference
bom-ref.description:
An identifier which can be used to reference the occurrence elsewhere in the BOM. Every `bom-ref` must be unique within the BOM.
Value SHOULD not start with the BOM-Link intro 'urn:cdx:' to avoid conflicts with BOM-Links.

location.title: Location
location.description: The location or path to where the component was found.

line.title: Line Number
line.description: The line number where the component was found.

offset.title: Offset
offset.description: The offset where the component was found.

symbol.title: Symbol
symbol.description: The symbol name that was found associated with the component.

additionalContext.title: Additional Context
additionalContext.description: Any additional context of the detected component (e.g. a code snippet).

callstack.title: Call Stack
callstack.description: Evidence of the components use through the callstack.

frames.title: Frames
frames.description: Within a call stack, a frame is a discrete unit that encapsulates an execution context, including local variables, parameters, and the return address. As function calls are made, frames are pushed onto the stack, forming an array-like structure that orchestrates the flow of program execution and manages the sequence of function invocations.

package.title: Package
package.description: A package organizes modules into namespaces, providing a unique namespace for each type it contains.

module.title: Module
module.description: A module or class that encloses functions/methods and other code.

function.title: Function
function.description: A block of code designed to perform a particular task.

parameters.title: Parameters
parameters.description: Arguments that are passed to the module or function.

line.title: Line
line.description: The line number the code that is called resides on.

column.title: Column
column.description: The column the code that is called resides.

fullFilename.title: Full Filename
fullFilename.description: The full path and filename of the module.

componentIdentityEvidence.title: Identity Evidence
componentIdentityEvidence.description: Evidence that substantiates the identity of a component.

field.title: Field
field.description: The identity field of the component which the evidence describes.

confidence.title: Confidence
confidence.description: The overall confidence of the evidence from 0 - 1, where 1 is 100% confidence.

concludedValue.title: Concluded Value
concludedValue.description: The value of the field (cpe, purl, etc) that has been concluded based on the aggregate of all methods (if available).

methods.title: Methods
methods.description: The methods used to extract and/or analyze the evidence.

technique.title: Technique
technique.description: The technique used in this method of analysis.

confidence.title: Confidence
confidence.description: The confidence of the evidence from 0 - 1, where 1 is 100% confidence. Confidence is specific to the technique used. Each technique of analysis can have independent confidence.

value.title: Value
value.description: The value or contents of the evidence.

tools.title: BOM References
tools.description: The object in the BOM identified by its bom-ref. This is often a component or service but may be any object type supporting bom-refs. Tools used for analysis should already be defined in the BOM, either in the metadata/tools, components, or formulation.

bom-ref.title: BOM Reference
bom-ref.description:
An identifier which can be used to reference the dataset elsewhere in the BOM. Every `bom-ref` must be unique within the BOM.
Value SHOULD not start with the BOM-Link intro 'urn:cdx:' to avoid conflicts with BOM-Links.

type.title: Type of Data
type.description: The general theme or subject matter of the data being specified.

meta:enum.source-code: Any type of code, code snippet, or data-as-code.
meta:enum.configuration: Parameters or settings that may be used by other components.
meta:enum.definition: Data that can be used to create new instances of what the definition defines.
meta:enum.other: Any other type of data that does not fit into existing definitions.

contents.title: Data Contents
contents.description: The contents or references to the contents of the data being described.

attachment.title: Data Attachment
attachment.description: A way to include textual or encoded data.

url.title: Data URL
url.description: The URL to where the data can be retrieved.

properties.title: Configuration Properties
properties.description: Provides the ability to document name-value parameters used for configuration.

sensitiveData.title: Sensitive Data
sensitiveData.description: A description of any sensitive data in a dataset.

description.title: Dataset Description
description.description: A description of the dataset. Can describe size of dataset, whether it's used for source code, training, testing, or validation, etc.

compositions.title: Compositions
compositions.description: Compositions describe constituent parts (including components, services, and dependency relationships) and their completeness. The completeness of vulnerabilities expressed in a BOM may also be described.

bom-ref.title: BOM Reference
bom-ref.description:
An identifier which can be used to reference the composition elsewhere in the BOM. Every `bom-ref` must be unique within the BOM.
Value SHOULD not start with the BOM-Link intro 'urn:cdx:' to avoid conflicts with BOM-Links.

aggregate.title: Aggregate
aggregate.description: Specifies an aggregate type that describes how complete a relationship is.

assemblies.title: BOM references
assemblies.description: The bom-ref identifiers of the components or services being described. Assemblies refer to nested relationships whereby a constituent part may include other constituent parts. References do not cascade to child parts. References are explicit for the specified constituent part only.

dependencies.title: BOM references
dependencies.description: The bom-ref identifiers of the components or services being described. Dependencies refer to a relationship whereby an independent constituent part requires another independent constituent part. References do not cascade to transitive dependencies. References are explicit for the specified dependency only.

vulnerabilities.title: BOM references
vulnerabilities.description: The bom-ref identifiers of the vulnerabilities being described.

meta:enum.complete: The relationship is complete. No further relationships including constituent components, services, or dependencies are known to exist.
meta:enum.incomplete: The relationship is incomplete. Additional relationships exist and may include constituent components, services, or dependencies.
meta:enum.incomplete_first_party_only: The relationship is incomplete. Only relationships for first-party components, services, or their dependencies are represented.
meta:enum.incomplete_first_party_proprietary_only: The relationship is incomplete. Only relationships for first-party components, services, or their dependencies are represented, limited specifically to those that are proprietary.
meta:enum.incomplete_first_party_opensource_only: The relationship is incomplete. Only relationships for first-party components, services, or their dependencies are represented, limited specifically to those that are opensource.
meta:enum.incomplete_third_party_only: The relationship is incomplete. Only relationships for third-party components, services, or their dependencies are represented.
meta:enum.incomplete_third_party_proprietary_only: The relationship is incomplete. Only relationships for third-party components, services, or their dependencies are represented, limited specifically to those that are proprietary.
meta:enum.incomplete_third_party_opensource_only: The relationship is incomplete. Only relationships for third-party components, services, or their dependencies are represented, limited specifically to those that are opensource.
meta:enum.unknown: The relationship may be complete or incomplete. This usually signifies a 'best-effort' to obtain constituent components, services, or dependencies but the completeness is inconclusive.
meta:enum.not_specified: The relationship completeness is not specified.

cryptoProperties.title: Cryptographic Properties
cryptoProperties.description: Cryptographic assets have properties that uniquely define them and that make them actionable for further reasoning. As an example, it makes a difference if one knows the algorithm family (e.g. AES) or the specific variant or instantiation (e.g. AES-128-GCM). This is because the security level and the algorithm primitive (authenticated encryption) are only defined by the definition of the algorithm variant. The presence of a weak cryptographic algorithm like SHA1 vs. HMAC-SHA1 also makes a difference.

assetType.title: Asset Type
assetType.description: Cryptographic assets occur in several forms. Algorithms and protocols are most commonly implemented in specialized cryptographic libraries. They may, however, also be 'hardcoded' in software components. Certificates and related cryptographic material like keys, tokens, secrets or passwords are other cryptographic assets to be modelled.

meta:enum.algorithm: Mathematical function commonly used for data encryption, authentication, and digital signatures.
meta:enum.certificate: An electronic document that is used to provide the identity or validate a public key.
meta:enum.protocol: A set of rules and guidelines that govern the behavior and communication with each other.
meta:enum.related-crypto-material: Other cryptographic assets related to algorithms, certificates, and protocols such as keys and tokens.

algorithmProperties.title: Algorithm Properties
algorithmProperties.description: Additional properties specific to a cryptographic algorithm.

primitive.title: primitive
primitive.description: Cryptographic building blocks used in higher-level cryptographic systems and protocols. Primitives represent different cryptographic routines: deterministic random bit generators (drbg, e.g. CTR_DRBG from NIST SP800-90A-r1), message authentication codes (mac, e.g. HMAC-SHA-256), blockciphers (e.g. AES), streamciphers (e.g. Salsa20), signatures (e.g. ECDSA), hash functions (e.g. SHA-256), public-key encryption schemes (pke, e.g. RSA), extended output functions (xof, e.g. SHAKE256), key derivation functions (e.g. pbkdf2), key agreement algorithms (e.g. ECDH), key encapsulation mechanisms (e.g. ML-KEM), authenticated encryption (ae, e.g. AES-GCM) and the combination of multiple algorithms (combiner, e.g. SP800-56Cr2).

meta:enum.drbg: Deterministic Random Bit Generator (DRBG) is a type of pseudorandom number generator designed to produce a sequence of bits from an initial seed value. DRBGs are commonly used in cryptographic applications where reproducibility of random values is important.
meta:enum.mac: In cryptography, a Message Authentication Code (MAC) is information used for authenticating and integrity-checking a message.
meta:enum.block-cipher: A block cipher is a symmetric key algorithm that operates on fixed-size blocks of data. It encrypts or decrypts the data in block units, providing confidentiality. Block ciphers are widely used in various cryptographic modes and protocols for secure data transmission.
meta:enum.stream-cipher: A stream cipher is a symmetric key cipher where plaintext digits are combined with a pseudorandom cipher digit stream (keystream).
meta:enum.signature: In cryptography, a signature is a digital representation of a message or data that proves its origin, identity, and integrity. Digital signatures are generated using cryptographic algorithms and are widely used for authentication and verification in secure communication.
meta:enum.hash: A hash function is a mathematical algorithm that takes an input (or 'message') and produces a fixed-size string of characters, which is typically a hash value. Hash functions are commonly used in various cryptographic applications, including data integrity verification and password hashing.
meta:enum.pke: Public Key Encryption (PKE) is a type of encryption that uses a pair of public and private keys for secure communication. The public key is used for encryption, while the private key is used for decryption. PKE is a fundamental component of public-key cryptography.
meta:enum.xof: An XOF is an extendable output function that can take arbitrary input and creates a stream of output, up to a limit determined by the size of the internal state of the hash function that underlies the XOF.
meta:enum.kdf: A Key Derivation Function (KDF) derives key material from another source of entropy while preserving the entropy of the input.
meta:enum.key-agree: In cryptography, a key-agreement is a protocol whereby two or more parties agree on a cryptographic key in such a way that both influence the outcome.
meta:enum.kem: A Key Encapsulation Mechanism (KEM) algorithm is a mechanism for transporting random keying material to a recipient using the recipient's public key.
meta:enum.ae: Authenticated Encryption (AE) is a cryptographic process that provides both confidentiality and data integrity. It ensures that the encrypted data has not been tampered with and comes from a legitimate source. AE is commonly used in secure communication protocols.
meta:enum.combiner: A combiner aggregates many candidates for a cryptographic primitive and generates a new candidate for the same primitive.
meta:enum.key-wrap: Key-wrap is a cryptographic technique used to securely encrypt and protect cryptographic keys using algorithms like AES.

algorithmFamily.title: Algorithm Family
algorithmFamily.description: A valid algorithm family identifier. If specified, this value shall be one of the enumeration of valid algorithm Family identifiers defined in the `cryptography-defs.schema.json` subschema.

parameterSetIdentifier.title: Parameter Set Identifier
parameterSetIdentifier.description: An identifier for the parameter set of the cryptographic algorithm. Examples: in AES128, '128' identifies the key length in bits, in SHA256, '256' identifies the digest length, '128' in SHAKE128 identifies its maximum security level in bits, and 'SHA2-128s' identifies a parameter set used in SLH-DSA (FIPS205).

ellipticCurve.title: Elliptic Curve
ellipticCurve.description: The specific underlying Elliptic Curve (EC) definition employed which is an indicator of the level of security strength, performance and complexity. If specified, this value shall be one of the enumeration of valid elliptic curves identifiers defined in the `cryptography-defs.schema.json` subschema.

executionEnvironment.title: Execution Environment
executionEnvironment.description: The target and execution environment in which the algorithm is implemented in.

meta:enum.software-plain-ram: A software implementation running in plain unencrypted RAM.
meta:enum.software-encrypted-ram: A software implementation running in encrypted RAM.
meta:enum.software-tee: A software implementation running in a trusted execution environment.
meta:enum.unknown: The execution environment is not known.

implementationPlatform.title: Implementation platform
implementationPlatform.description: The target platform for which the algorithm is implemented. The implementation can be 'generic', running on any platform or for a specific platform.

certificationLevel.title: Certification Level
certificationLevel.description: The certification that the implementation of the cryptographic algorithm has received, if any. Certifications include revisions and levels of FIPS 140 or Common Criteria of different Extended Assurance Levels (CC-EAL).

meta:enum.unknown: The certification level is not known

mode.title: Mode
mode.description: The mode of operation in which the cryptographic algorithm (block cipher) is used.

meta:enum.ccm: Counter with cipher block chaining message authentication code
meta:enum.unknown: The mode of operation is not known

padding.title: Padding
padding.description: The padding scheme that is used for the cryptographic algorithm.

meta:enum.pkcs5: Public Key Cryptography Standard: Password-Based Cryptography
meta:enum.pkcs7: Public Key Cryptography Standard: Cryptographic Message Syntax
meta:enum.pkcs1v15: Public Key Cryptography Standard: RSA Cryptography v1.5
meta:enum.unknown: The padding scheme is not known

cryptoFunctions.title: Cryptographic functions
cryptoFunctions.description: The cryptographic functions implemented by the cryptographic algorithm.

classicalSecurityLevel.title: classical security level
classicalSecurityLevel.description: The classical security level that a cryptographic algorithm provides (in bits).

nistQuantumSecurityLevel.title: NIST security strength category
nistQuantumSecurityLevel.description: The NIST security strength category as defined in https://csrc.nist.gov/projects/post-quantum-cryptography/post-quantum-cryptography-standardization/evaluation-criteria/security-(evaluation-criteria). A value of 0 indicates that none of the categories are met.

certificateProperties.title: Certificate Properties
certificateProperties.description: Properties for cryptographic assets of asset type 'certificate'.

serialNumber.title: Serial Number
serialNumber.description: The serial number is a unique identifier for the certificate issued by a CA.

subjectName.title: Subject Name
subjectName.description: The subject name for the certificate.

issuerName.title: Issuer Name
issuerName.description: The issuer name for the certificate.

notValidBefore.title: Not Valid Before
notValidBefore.description: The date and time according to ISO-8601 standard from which the certificate is valid.

notValidAfter.title: Not Valid After
notValidAfter.description: The date and time according to ISO-8601 standard from which the certificate is not valid anymore.

certificateFileExtension.title: Certificate File Extension
certificateFileExtension.description: The file extension of the certificate.

fingerprint.title: Certificate Fingerprint
fingerprint.description: The fingerprint is a cryptographic hash of the certificate excluding it's signature.

certificateState.title: Certificate Lifecycle State
certificateState.description: The certificate lifecycle is a comprehensive process that manages digital certificates from their initial creation to eventual expiration or revocation. It typically involves several stages.

state.title: State
state.description: A pre-defined state in the certificate lifecycle.

meta:enum.pre-activation: The certificate has been issued by the issuing certificate authority (CA) but has not been authorized for use.
meta:enum.active: The certificate may be used to cryptographically protect information, cryptographically process previously protected information, or both.
meta:enum.deactivated: Certificates in the deactivated state shall not be used to apply cryptographic protection but, in some cases, may be used to process cryptographically protected information.
meta:enum.suspended: The use of a certificate may be suspended for several possible reasons.
meta:enum.revoked: A revoked certificate is a digital certificate that has been invalidated by the issuing certificate authority (CA) before its scheduled expiration date.

reason.title: Reason
reason.description: A reason for the certificate being in this state.

name.title: State
name.description: The name of the certificate lifecycle state.

description.title: Description
description.description: The description of the certificate lifecycle state.

reason.title: Reason
reason.description: A reason for the certificate being in this state.

creationDate.title: Creation Date
creationDate.description: The date and time (timestamp) when the certificate was created or pre-activated.

activationDate.title: Activation Date
activationDate.description: The date and time (timestamp) when the certificate was activated.

deactivationDate.title: Deactivation Date
deactivationDate.description: The date and time (timestamp) when the related certificate was deactivated.

revocationDate.title: Revocation Date
revocationDate.description: The date and time (timestamp) when the certificate was revoked.

destructionDate.title: Destruction Date
destructionDate.description: The date and time (timestamp) when the certificate was destroyed.

certificateExtensions.title: Certificate Extensions
certificateExtensions.description: A certificate extension is a field that provides additional information about the certificate or its use. Extensions are used to convey additional information beyond the standard fields.

meta:enum.basicConstraints: Specifies whether a certificate can be used as a CA certificate or not.
meta:enum.keyUsage: Specifies the allowed uses of the public key in the certificate.
meta:enum.extendedKeyUsage: Specifies additional purposes for which the public key can be used.
meta:enum.subjectAlternativeName: Allows inclusion of additional names to identify the entity associated with the certificate.
meta:enum.authorityKeyIdentifier: Identifies the public key of the CA that issued the certificate.
meta:enum.subjectKeyIdentifier: Identifies the public key associated with the entity the certificate was issued to.
meta:enum.authorityInformationAccess: Contains CA issuers and OCSP information.
meta:enum.certificatePolicies: Defines the policies under which the certificate was issued and can be used.

licenseAcknowledgementEnumeration.title: License Acknowledgement
licenseAcknowledgementEnumeration.description: Declared licenses and concluded licenses represent two different stages in the licensing process within software development. Declared licenses refer to the initial intention of the software authors regarding the licensing terms under which their code is released. On the other hand, concluded licenses are the result of a comprehensive analysis of the project's codebase to identify and confirm the actual licenses of the components used, which may differ from the initially declared licenses. While declared licenses provide an upfront indication of the licensing intentions, concluded licenses offer a more thorough understanding of the actual licensing within a project, facilitating proper compliance and risk management. Observed licenses are defined in `@.evidence.licenses`. Observed licenses form the evidence necessary to substantiate a concluded license.

patent.description: A patent is a legal instrument, granted by an authority, that confers certain rights over an invention for a specified period, contingent on public disclosure and adherence to relevant legal requirements. publicationNumber.title: Patent Publication Number
publicationNumber.description:
This is the number assigned to a patent application once it is published. Patent applications are generally published 18 months after filing (unless an applicant requests non-publication). This number is distinct from the application number. 

Purpose: Identifies the publicly available version of the application. 

Format: Varies by jurisdiction, often similar to application numbers but includes an additional suffix indicating publication. 

Example:
 - US: US20240000123A1 (indicates the first publication of application US20240000123) 
 - Europe: EP23123456A1 (first publication of European application EP23123456). 

WIPO ST.96 v8.0: 
 - Publication Number field: https://www.wipo.int/standards/XMLSchema/ST96/V8_0/Patent/PublicationNumber.xsd

title.title: Patent Title
title.description: The title of the patent, summarising the invention it protects. Aligned with `InventionTitle` in WIPO ST.96. Refer to [InventionTitle in ST.96](https://www.wipo.int/standards/XMLSchema/ST96/V8_0/Patent/InventionTitle.xsd).

grantDate.description: The date the patent was granted by the jurisdiction. Aligned with `GrantDate` in WIPO ST.96. Refer to [GrantDate in ST.96](https://www.wipo.int/standards/XMLSchema/ST96/V8_0/Patent/GrantDate.xsd).

patentExpirationDate.title: Expiration Date
patentExpirationDate.description: The date the patent expires. Derived from grant or filing date according to jurisdiction-specific rules.

patentLegalStatus.title: Legal Status
patentLegalStatus.description: Indicates the current legal status of the patent or patent application, based on the WIPO ST.27 standard. This status reflects administrative, procedural, or legal events. Values include both active and inactive states and are useful for determining enforceability, procedural history, and maintenance status.

patentFamily.description: A patent family is a group of related patent applications or granted patents that cover the same or similar invention. These patents are filed in multiple jurisdictions to protect the invention across different regions or countries. A patent family typically includes patents that share a common priority date, originating from the same initial application, and may vary slightly in scope or claims to comply with regional legal frameworks. Formal registration is optional.

releaseType.description:
The software versioning type. It is recommended that the release type use one of 'major', 'minor', 'patch', 'pre-release', or 'internal'. Representing all possible software release types is not practical, so standardizing on the recommended values, whenever possible, is strongly encouraged.

* __major__ = A major release may contain significant changes or may introduce breaking changes.
* __minor__ = A minor release, also known as an update, may contain a smaller number of changes than major releases.
* __patch__ = Patch releases are typically unplanned and may resolve defects or important security issues.
* __pre-release__ = A pre-release may include alpha, beta, or release candidates and typically have limited support. They provide the ability to preview a release prior to its general availability.
* __internal__ = Internal releases are not for public consumption and are intended to be used exclusively by the project or manufacturer that produced it.

provider.title: Provider
provider.description: The organization that provides the service.

group.title: Service Group
group.description: The grouping name, namespace, or identifier. This will often be a shortened, single name of the company or project that produced the service or domain name. Whitespace and special characters should be avoided.

name.title: Service Name
name.description: The name of the service. This will often be a shortened, single name of the service.

description.title: Service Description
description.description: Specifies a description for the service

endpoints.title: Endpoints
endpoints.description: The endpoint URIs of the service. Multiple endpoints are allowed.

authenticated.title: Authentication Required
authenticated.description: A boolean value indicating if the service requires authentication. A value of true indicates the service requires authentication prior to use. A value of false indicates the service does not require authentication.

x-trust-boundary.title: Crosses Trust Boundary
x-trust-boundary.description: A boolean value indicating if use of the service crosses a trust zone or boundary. A value of true indicates that by using the service, a trust boundary is crossed. A value of false indicates that by using the service, a trust boundary is not crossed.

trustZone.title: Trust Zone
trustZone.description: The name of the trust zone the service resides in.

data.title: Data
data.description: Specifies information about the data including the directional flow of data and the data classification.

services.title: Services
services.description: A list of services included or deployed behind the parent service. This is not a dependency tree. It provides a way to specify a hierarchical representation of service assemblies.

flow.title: Directional Flow
flow.description: Specifies the flow direction of the data. Direction is relative to the service. Inbound flow states that data enters the service. Outbound flow states that data leaves the service. Bi-directional states that data flows both ways and unknown states that the direction is not known.

description.title: Description
description.description: Short description of the data content and usage
examples: Credit card information being exchanged in between the web app and the database

source.title: Source
source.description: The URI, URL, or BOM-Link of the components or services the data came in from

destination.title: Destination
destination.description: The URI, URL, or BOM-Link of the components or services the data is sent to

standards.title: Standards
standards.description: The list of standards which may consist of regulations, industry or organizational-specific standards, maturity models, best practices, or any other requirements which can be evaluated against or attested to.

standard.title: Standard
standard.description: A standard may consist of regulations, industry or organizational-specific standards, maturity models, best practices, or any other requirements which can be evaluated against or attested to.

name.title: Name

description.title: Description

text.title: Text

descriptions.title: Descriptions
descriptions.description: The supplemental text that provides additional guidance or context to the requirement, but is not directly part of the requirement.

openCre.title: OWASP OpenCRE Identifier(s)
openCre.description: The Common Requirements Enumeration (CRE) identifier(s). CRE is a structured and standardized framework for uniting security standards and guidelines. CRE links each section of a resource to a shared topic identifier (a Common Requirement). Through this shared topic link, all resources map to each other. Use of CRE promotes clear and unambiguous communication among stakeholders.

parent.title: Parent BOM Reference
parent.description: The `bom-ref` to a parent requirement. This establishes a hierarchy of requirements. Top-level requirements must not define a parent. Only child requirements should define parents.

levels.title: Levels
levels.description: The list of levels associated with the standard. Some standards have different levels of compliance.

description.title: Description

requirements.title: Requirements

threatCategory.description: Threat category based on methodology (e.g., STRIDE category)

meta:enum.indirect: Weakness is indirectly caused by another weakness
